appearance:
1.The surface exhibits ejector marks (differences in gloss, stress whitening and deformation).
2.The surface exhibits ejector marks (differences in gloss, stress whitening and deformation).
3.Warpage
cause:
1.Demolding system: too few or incorrectly positioned ejector pins or the effective surface area of the pins is too small.
2.Undercuts, scratches or grooves.
3.Unsuitable geometry of the moldings, e.g. a highly or disadvantageously ribbed part.
4.Shrinkage on the core during molding/cooling. Ejected part temperature too high. Ejector speed/pressure too high.
5.Overpacking the molded part.
6.Inadequate drafts. Draft not matched to the surface structure.
7.Unbalanced mold temperature.
correction:
1.Make sure deformation occurs during ejection and is not actually warpage.
2.Optimize the demolding system. Ensure sufficient number of ejector pins. Ejector pins should be placed in areas where high demolding forces are expected (e.g. ribs)
3.Check mold for regular surface condition and if necessary remedy any defects.
4.Design the molding in line with the nature of the plastic.
5.Cool core more intensively. Increase cooling time, reduce ejector speed/pressure.
6.Increase the setting time, check changeover from injection pressure to holding pressure (avoid overpacking) and reduce holding pressure. Enlarge the drafts.
7.Reduce cavity pressure through injection speed and melt temperature.

picture.caption: Fig. 10.1: Ejector marks due to the effective surface area of the ejector pins being too small
Fig. 10.2: Deformed part as a result of overpacking and shrinkage onto the core of the mold
Fig. 10.3: Demolding fracture; an excessively large undercut causes the bracket to be torn off
